bibl.title: Letter from A.V. McClain to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1941

div1.p: McClain writes that he will send Hench a package of "A Mile Post" brochures. He reports that there are no additional copies of Alumni Bulletins. The film made during Founders' Day celebration at the college turned out well.

div1.head: Letter from A.V. McClain to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1941
div1.opener:
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
January 30, 1941
ASSISTANT TO THE PRESIDENT
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have been away on a vacation and have just
read your letter of January 22nd. I had a package of
“Mile Posts” which I had put away and which I am sending
you under separate cover. I understand that no Alumni
Bulletins are available. I think there are about fifty
booklets in the package I am sending you and hope they
will help you in what you are trying to do.

Our film turned out fairly well. If you wish,
I will be glad to send it to you so that you can see the
parts I had copied from still pictures. It was my inten-
tion to have some extra footage made for you but either
no extra footage was made or the extra footage was used
in the film. I did not put it together myself. If you
want to see it, you could indicate what scenes you would
like to have and I will have them made for you. Scenes
in the film were taken by quite a number of persons and
some of them are not good, but since it is all we have
I had them included. It makes a fairly good historical
record, nevertheless.

I am glad to read your remarks about the
“special edition”. After we received your wire I was a
little apprehensive less you were made too uncomfortable.
Consequently, I am glad you had a laugh out of it. I
realize that I will have to be on my guard for what may
happen.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, A. V. McClain Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
